question: I don’t think the law will interfere with us as we are just trying to turn an honest penny.
Teachers of various schools (1)/met to discuss about (2) how to improve the standard of English. (3)/ No error. (4).
answer:
The error lies in part (2) of the sentence. The preposition ‘about’ has superfluously been used here.

For example:

We discussed when to go/when we should go.

question: In sprit of the immense pressure exerted by the militants, the Government has decided not to give in.
We want to keep gift as a surprise for mother but by sister gave the game away.
The young and old sat cheek by jowl in the large audience.
The two first of arrive (1)/ were the lucky recipients (2)/ of a surprise gift. (3)/ No error (4)
answer: “The two first to arrive” should be replaced with ‘the first two of arrive’ to make a correct sense of the sentences.

question: The watchdogs were asleep when the bulls ran riot.
Scarcely had (1)/ I arrived than (2)/ the train left. (3)/ No error. (4).
answer:
Scarcely should be followed by when and not by than.

For example:

Scarcely had he gone, when(not than) a policeman knocked at the door.

Hence, than should be replaced by when.

question: His tradition-bound attitude (1)/ had to be constant source of dissatisfaction (2)/ among the young members of the family (3)/No error. (4).
The reason why (1)/ he was rejected (2) was because he was too young. (3)/ No error. (4).
answer:
After such opening as The reason is, the reason why, the clause, containing the reason must being with ‘because’ but with ‘that’.

For example:

The reason why he is absent is that he is ill. Hence because should be replaced with that.
